title: How to Set up for Natural Light Photography

steps.headline: Make sure your camera is set to get the look you want.
steps.description: You will want to modify your shutter speed, ISO, and aperture. If your speed is set for more than 1/60th of a second, be sure to use a tripod.

steps.headline: Look at the room (if inside) or the surrounding area (if outside) and see where the best place is for taking the photograph.
Put your subject where you think you want them.
steps.description: Take a test shot to see what you are looking at for results. If your subject is washed out, then they are too close to too much light. Move them away from the light or into the shadows, somewhat.

steps.headline: If using shadows, be sure the shadows are pretty consistent.
steps.description: Otherwise, your exposure will be off.

steps.headline: If outside, don't have your subject facing the sun (effectively behind the photographer's back).
steps.description: That is a holdover from the Kodak does and mostly accomplishes squinted eyes and washed out images.

steps.headline: Use a reflector.
steps.description: This creates a nice fill light if used properly. You can buy them from many sources, or you can go to your local store and buy a large poster card and use it as a reflector. Your main choices are a silver reflector or white. However, many vendors have a third option, a gold reflector.

steps.headline: Be sure there is a light-colored flat surface near them.
steps.description: You are using it for its reflective qualities. If you don't have one, don't worry about it.

steps.headline: Move the reflectors around.
steps.description: You will be amazed at the difference that moving its angle or location will make.

steps.headline: Be sure that the main light is at an angle to your subject.
steps.description: For outside photography, that is the best option. It adds texture and definition to your image.

If your speed is set for more than 1/60th of a second, be sure to use a tripod. Look at the room (if inside) or the surrounding area (if outside) and see where the best place is for taking the photograph.  Put your subject where you think you want them. Take a test shot to see what you are looking at for results. If your subject is washed out, then they are too close to too much light. Move them away from the light or into the shadows, somewhat. If using shadows, be sure the shadows are pretty consistent. Otherwise, your exposure will be off. If outside, don't have your subject facing the sun (effectively behind the photographer's back). That is a holdover from the Kodak does and mostly accomplishes squinted eyes and washed out images. Use a reflector. This creates a nice fill light if used properly. You can buy them from many sources, or you can go to your local store and buy a large poster card and use it as a reflector. Your main choices are a silver reflector or white. However, many vendors have a third option, a gold reflector. Be sure there is a light-colored flat surface near them. You are using it for its reflective qualities. If you don't have one, don't worry about it. Move the reflectors around. You will be amazed at the difference that moving its angle or location will make. Be sure that the main light is at an angle to your subject. For outside photography, that is the best option. It adds texture and definition to your image.
